title: Emergence of 'Contact English'
description: English arrives in West Africa through British trading forts along the coast in the 17th century. This marks the beginning of English presence in the region, although in a limited capacity. During this period, a rudimentary form of 'contact English' develops, laying the groundwork for future linguistic interactions.

title: The Niger Expedition
description: The British-backed expedition aimed to form treaties, introduce Christianity, and boost trade with native communities. This marked an early effort to establish British influence and interactions in the region, impacting subsequent socio-cultural exchanges and the introduction of English language and Christianity.

title: Lagos as a British Colony
description: Lagos officially becomes a British colony, signifying a significant step in British colonial rule in Nigeria. This transition brings about changes in governance, administration, and cultural influences, including the spread of English language and Western education.

title: Royal Niger Company Charter
description: The charter of the Royal Niger Company consolidates British interests in the region. This period witnesses intensified British economic and administrative involvement, fostering the introduction and spread of English as a language of trade and governance.

title: Nigeria as Protectorates
description: Northern and Southern Nigeria are declared protectorates, attracting increased presence of soldiers, government officials, and personnel. This influx contributes to the further establishment of English as an administrative language and in educational institutions.

title: Unification and British Rule
description: Nigeria is unified as a British colony, ushering in significant changes under British rule, including the promotion of Western education, the English language, and Christianity. This period solidifies English as a language of governance, education, and cultural dissemination.

title: Establishment of the University of Ibadan
description: The founding of the University of Ibadan, the first Nigerian university, further cements English as the language of higher education and academic discourse, fostering its role in intellectual and scholarly pursuits.

title: Nigeria's Independence
description: Nigeria gains independence, and English remains the official language due to the multi-ethnic and multilingual nature of the country. This decision prevents the dominance of any single ethnic language, promoting unity while allowing diverse linguistic identities to coexist.

title: British Cameroons Referendum
description: The referendum results in the northern part of British Cameroons joining Nigeria, while the southern part unites with French Cameroon. This event impacts linguistic borders and influences English usage and interactions in the region.

title: National Policy on Education
description: Nigeria adopts a National Policy on Education emphasizing the use of English as the language of instruction in schools. This formalizes English as the primary medium of instruction, shaping educational practices across the country.

title: Declaration of Kenya as a Protectorate
description: Kenya is declared a British protectorate, marking the onset of British colonial rule. This period witnesses the initial establishment of British influence and administration in the region.

title: Construction of the East African Railway
description: The construction of the railway connecting the East African coast to Lake Victoria promotes transportation and trade. This infrastructure project facilitates interactions among diverse communities, impacting language interactions and cultural exchanges.

title: Relocation of Capital to Nairobi
description: The capital of the British colony shifts from Mombasa to Nairobi. This move has lasting linguistic implications as Nairobi, initially dominated by Masai and Kikuyu populations, sees a shift away from Swahili influence, altering the linguistic landscape.

title: Arrival of British Settlers
description: More British settlers arrive in Kenya following the opportunities for profitable farming brought about by the railway. Their impact on spreading English among Africans is limited, and they adopt Swahili for their own purposes, affecting language dynamics.

title: Kenya as a British Colony
description: Kenya becomes a formal British colony, solidifying British control and governance structures. This period marks the formalization of British administration and policies in the region.

title: Growth of Missionary Activities
description: Expansion of missionary activities introduces English language instruction alongside religious teachings. Missionary schools play a significant role in spreading English literacy among local communities.

title: Language Policy Commissions
description: The establishment of language policy commissions, such as the Phelps-Stokes and The East Africa Commission in 1925, explores language introduction levels in the education system. These inquiries shape the role and prominence of English in education.

title: Mau Mau Rebellion
description: The Mau Mau rebellion erupts, leading to a state of emergency in Kenya. This period witnesses significant unrest and resistance against British colonial rule, impacting social, political, and educational structures.

title: Educational Shift due to Mau Mau Rebellion
description: As a response to the Mau Mau rebellion, the administration of schools transitions to District Education Boards consisting of patriotic nationalists and English administrators. This pivotal shift in educational administration results in the promotion of British ideology, emphasizing the teaching of English and history in schools.

title: Kenya's Independence
description: Kenya gains independence, and English remains in official use. Despite gaining independence, English continues as an official language, maintaining its role in governance, education, and national communication alongside Swahili.

title: Early Arrival of English
description: English initially arrives in Cameroon during the 16th century through British and Dutch slave depots at the coast of Bimbia. It gains more prominence in the 17th century, introduced by British missionaries engaged in evangelism, which significantly contributes to its initial spread.

title: Introduction of English in Education
description: Cameroon establishes its first primary school in Bimbia in 1844, where English serves as the language of instruction. This marks an early formal use of English in educational settings in Cameroon.

title: German Protectorate and Birth of Cameroon Pidgin English
description: Cameroon is established as a German protectorate. Cameroon Pidgin English emerges in German-owned plantations and quickly spreads among the multiethnic workers.

title: British Cameroons as a League of Nations Mandate
description: British Cameroons becomes a League of Nations mandate. The new colonial administrators aim to impose English and their languages in education and administration, shaping linguistic policies in the acquired territory.

title: Language Policy in Education
description: British language policies in African education initially consider the cognitive and sociocultural development of children, attempting to introduce the mother tongue as a language of instruction. However, English eventually supersedes the use of the mother tongue in primary education.

title: Language Bilingualism in Cameroon
description: A referendum divides British Cameroons, leading to the northern part joining Nigeria while the southern part unites with French Cameroon. This event establishes English and French as the official languages of Cameroon, embracing a policy of official language bilingualism.

title: Creation of a Unitary State
description: Cameroon establishes a unitary state consisting of seven provinces, setting the groundwork for administrative structures and regional divisions.

title: Expansion of Administrative Regions
description: Through a Presidential decree, the number of provinces increases to ten, creating ten administrative regions. This division includes two English-speaking regions and eight French-speaking regions, shaping the linguistic and administrative landscape of Cameroon.

title: Anglophone Crisis
description: The onset of the Anglophone Crisis, marked by protests and tensions in predominantly English-speaking regions, brings attention to issues of linguistic rights, political marginalization, and the perceived neglect of English-speaking communities in Cameroon.

title: Bilingualism Commission and National Dialogue
description: The establishment of the National Commission for the Promotion of Bilingualism and Multiculturalism signifies efforts to address linguistic and cultural tensions. This initiative aims to foster better integration and cooperation between English and French speakers in Cameroon.
